comment.text: Converts sphingomyelin to ceramide (PubMed:1840600, PubMed:18815062, PubMed:27659707, PubMed:25920558). Also has phospholipase C activities toward 1,2-diacylglycerolphosphocholine and 1,2-diacylglycerolphosphoglycerol.
Isoform 2 lacks residues that bind the cofactor Zn(2+) and has no enzyme activity.
Isoform 3 lacks residues that bind the cofactor Zn(2+) and has no enzyme activity.
Binds 2 Zn(2+) ions per subunit (PubMed:27349982, PubMed:27725636). Zn(2+) is particularly important for enzyme activity at neutral pH (PubMed:8702487).
A common polymorphism arises from a variable number of hexanucleotide repeat sequence within the signal peptide region.

disease.name: Niemann-Pick disease A
disease.description: An early-onset lysosomal storage disorder caused by failure to hydrolyze sphingomyelin to ceramide. It results in the accumulation of sphingomyelin and other metabolically related lipids in reticuloendothelial and other cell types throughout the body, leading to cell death. Niemann-Pick disease type A is a primarily neurodegenerative disorder characterized by onset within the first year of life, mental retardation, digestive disorders, failure to thrive, major hepatosplenomegaly, and severe neurologic symptoms. The severe neurological disorders and pulmonary infections lead to an early death, often around the age of four. Clinical features are variable. A phenotypic continuum exists between type A (basic neurovisceral) and type B (purely visceral) forms of Niemann-Pick disease, and the intermediate types encompass a cluster of variants combining clinical features of both types A and B.

comment.text: The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.

disease.name: Niemann-Pick disease B
disease.description: A late-onset lysosomal storage disorder caused by failure to hydrolyze sphingomyelin to ceramide. It results in the accumulation of sphingomyelin and other metabolically related lipids in reticuloendothelial and other cell types throughout the body, leading to cell death. Clinical signs involve only visceral organs. The most constant sign is hepatosplenomegaly which can be associated with pulmonary symptoms. Patients remain free of neurologic manifestations. However, a phenotypic continuum exists between type A (basic neurovisceral) and type B (purely visceral) forms of Niemann-Pick disease, and the intermediate types encompass a cluster of variants combining clinical features of both types A and B. In Niemann-Pick disease type B, onset of the first symptoms occurs in early childhood and patients can survive into adulthood.

comment.text: The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
There are two types of sphingomyelinases: ASM (acid), and NSM (neutral).
Belongs to the acid sphingomyelinase family.

Variants Gln-294 and Val-485 have been originally reported as disease-causing mutations in NPDA and NPDB (PubMed:12369017, PubMed:15221801). These variants have been reclassified as benign polymorphisms (PubMed:23430512).

comment.name: Mendelian genes sphingomyelin phosphodiesterase 1, acid lysosomal (SMPD1)

property.value: F:hydrolase activity, acting on glycosyl bonds
P:negative regulation of MAP kinase activity

feature.description: Polymorphism; does not affect enzymatic activity; dbSNP:rs1050228.
In NPDA and NPDB; expresses protein level comparable to wild-type SMPD1 expressing cells; retains very low enzyme activity.
In NPDB; expresses protein level comparable to wild-type SMPD1 expressing cells; retains 13% residual enzyme activity.
In NPDB; also in patients with an intermediate form.
In NPDA; reduces enzyme activity; intermediate form with clinical features of both Niemann-Pick disease types A and B.
In NPDA; results in less than 0.5% of wild-type activity.
In NPDB; expresses protein level comparable to wild-type SMPD1 expressing cells; retains no enzyme activity.
In NPDB and NPDA; some patients have a NPDA/NPDB intermediate phenotype.
In NPDA; intermediate form with clinical features of both Niemann-Pick disease types A and B.
In NPDA; intermediate form with clinical features of both Niemann-Pick disease types A and B.
In NPDB; expresses protein level comparable to wild-type SMPD1 expressing cells; retains no enzyme activity.
In NPDA; severe decrease in activity; the mutant is highly unstable.
In NPDA and NPDB; also found in patients with an intermediate form.
In NPDA; strongly reduces enzyme activity; intermediate form with clinical features of both Niemann-Pick disease types A and B.
In NPDA; results in loss of activity.
In NPDA; strongly reduces enzyme activity; intermediate form with clinical features of both Niemann-Pick disease types A and B.
In NPDB; expresses protein level comparable to wild-type SMPD1 expressing cells; retains no enzyme activity.
In NPDB; also in patients with an intermediate form; unknown pathological significance.
In NPDA; strongly reduces enzyme activity; intermediate form with clinical features of both Niemann-Pick disease types A and B.
In NPDA; in 23% of NPDA Ashkenazi Jewish patients; abolishes enzyme activity.
In NPDB; results in 20% of wild-type activity.
In NPDB; results in 1-4% of wild type activity.
In NPDA; strongly reduces enzyme activity; intermediate form with clinical features of both Niemann-Pick disease types A and B.

In NPDB; sphingomyelinase activity is decreased to 4% of wild-type activity; no effect on protein abundance; no effect on protein localization to lysosome; no effect on protein localization to extracellular space.
In NPDB; reduces enzyme activity; some patients have a NPDA/NPDB intermediate phenotype.
In NPDB; low sphingomyelin degradation rates.
In NPDB; results in loss of activity; the patient also carries mutation H-228 that has sufficient activity to account for the Niemann-Pick disease type B phenotype.
In NPDB; some patients have a NPDA/NPDB intermediate phenotype.
Polymorphism; does not affect enzymatic activity; dbSNP:rs141641266.
In NPDA; in 32% of NPDA Ashkenazi Jewish patients; nearly abolishes enzyme activity.
Polymorphism; does not affect enzymatic activity; dbSNP:rs1050239.
In NPDB; results in 64% of wild-type activity.
In NPDB and NPDA; also in patients with an intermediate form.
In NPDB; expresses protein level comparable to wild-type SMPD1 expressing cells; retains 6.8% residual enzyme activity.
In NPDA; results in decreased activity; decreased stability.
In NPDA; impairs enzyme activity; also in patients with an intermediate form.
In NPDB and NPDA; expresses protein level comparable to wild-type SMPD1 expressing cells; retains about 10% residual enzyme activity.
In NPDB; expresses protein level comparable to wild-type SMPD1 expressing cells; retains very low enzyme activity.
In NPDB; nearly abolishes enzyme activity; some patients have a NPDA/NPDB intermediate phenotype.
